data: Iscrizione greche del museo civico di Termini Imerese
Antonietta Brugnone, «Iscrizione greche del museo civico di Termini Imerese», Kokalos 20 (1974): 218–64
Dedication to Aphrodite by the city magistrates
The text is approximately centred, but with a notable bias to the left; only the final line fills the entire width of the face. The spacing between lines is somewhat irregular.

Plainly cut letters without serifs, of slightly irregular width and height. Alpha has a straight bar, sometimes with curvature; epsilon has shorter middle bar; theta has a detached middle bar; kappa with near full length arms; mu with vertical first and last, middle strokes not fully descending and curving at apex; omicron slihgtly smaller and above the line; pi has equal length verticals and overlapping horizontal; sigma has parallel outer strokes, half-width mid-strokes with curving apex; upsilon has straight arms;l phi has oval eye and extended vertical; omega is circular, open at the base, with horizontal feet.
mid-third to mid-second century BCE on the basis of the lettering.
I.Sicily with the permission of the Assessorato Regionale dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana - Dipartimento dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana; photo J. Prag 2018-07-10
Fiorelli, 1876-, Notizie degli scavi di antichità

Honours for an individual who undertook public building works
The text appears to be laid out with a more or less consistent left margin, vacats to the right.

Regularly cut letters with terminal serifs including horizontal caps to the tops of the alphas. Alpha has generally curved crossbar, sometimes equivalent to broken bar; epsilon has detached middle bar in the form of a triangle; theta has central point; kappa has full-length arms; omicron is full-size; pi has equal length verticals and overlapping horizontal; rho has a tapering eye; sigma has horizontal top and bottom, which overextend to left, the mid-strokes extending halfway, and straight; upsilon has straight arms; omega is tear-drop shaped, and closed, on a horizontal line.
Gualtherus, 1624, Siciliae obiacentium insular et Bruttiorum antiquae tabulae cum animadversionibus Georgii Gualtheri
Gualtherus, 1624 [1625], Siciliæ obiacentium insular. et Bruttiorum antiquæ tabulæ, cum animadversionib

Four lines of fragmentary Greek text.

Letters are very thin, and chiselling is rough and uneven. Letters are unevenly spaced. Small serifs on letters. Use of cursive omega; line 2 xi in plaster cast has a mid-line which slopes upwards; upsilon in lines 2 and 4 are shaped like a lower-case alphabetic 'Y'.

1Α(vac.1)Π
2ΚΛΞΚΒΥΩ
3ΘΖΝΛΩ
4ΕΓΕ(vac.1)ΥΒ

Letters are extremely thin, and curved. The first vertical stem of the eta in line 2 appears to join the vertical stem of the kappa in line 1, thus making it difficult to be precise about letter heights in lines 1-2. The orthography is extremely strange, particularly in the tail of the tau in line 3 which gives the impression of the letter 'J'.
Brugnone doubts authenticity, on grounds of type of marble, and letter forms (?)

1Μάξιμος
2Διδύμου υἱὸς
3ἔζησεν ἔτη κγ´
Funerary inscription for a family, including Nemenidas and Cleopatra

Text is divided into two bands. The top band is separated into three columns, with a thin, serifed vertical line on a slight tilt between each column of text. Each column contains three lines of Greek. The bottom band contains three lines of continuous text, although with a vacat in the first line. Large empty vacat at the bottom of the stone.

Use of alphas with broken mid-bar in top band, but not in bottom. Use of epsilon with arrow crossbar in top band, but not bottom (except for one instance in line 4). Use of lunate epsilon in bottom band, but not in top. Use of lunate sigma in bottom text. Serifs more pronounced in top band. In the top text, Omegas are smaller consistently than the rest of the text. Text in bottom band is carved lightly and irregularly. As Brugnone notes, it seems likely that the lower section was cut by a different hand.
funerary inscription for a family, including nemenidas and cleopatra

Funerary inscription to Olos Papios Agatharchos
Three lines of Greek text. Text is not aligned with centre of stone, with a more significant vacat on right side of the stone than the left. End of line 1 obscured by damaged top right corner.
Some serifs are used, particularly on the epsilons. Spacing, especially in line 1, is irregular. Teardrop shaped omega in line 1. All alphas have a broken mid-bar.
Korhonen, 2001, Osservazioni sul collezionismo epigrafico siciliano
funerary inscription to olos papios agatharchos

1Ὦλε Πάπ̣ιε
2Ἀγάθαρχε
3χαῖρε
Three lines of Greek text. Text is left justified.

Letters are fairly regularly spaced in lines 1-2, but become more irregular in line 3. Letters have light serifs. Letter forms irregular and inconsistent. Two forms of alpha are used: in line one, alpha has an oblique mid-bar which slopes to the right, in lines 2-3, alpha has a broken mid-bar. Omega in line 1 is flat and broad. Beta in line 3 is extremely flat and pointed, and is potentially a correction from a Rho.

1Ὀπετρηία Λητώι Μου-
2σαίου γυνήι χαῖρε χρησ-
3τὴ καὶ εὐσεβής
Funerary inscription for Gaios Seios Ptolemaios
Four lines of Ancient Greek text. Text is contained within right side of tabula ansata. Text is centred on stone.

Greek text is straight, with crisp and well-defined letter forms. Extremely regular in layout and in spaces between letters. Serifs used on most letters. The middle lines of epsilons are formed as right-pointing triangles, but in line 4 is formed as an arrow instead. Broken-bar alphas are used throughout.
Noy, 1993, Jewish inscriptions of Western Europe
funerary inscription for gaios seios ptolemaios

Three lines of Greek text, roughly centred on stone. Clear use of inscribed guidelines on top and bottom of each line.

Letters are extremely regular and neat, with letter heights all identical (except for phi in line 1, which extends above the guideline). Letters are thin, tall and evenly spaced. Terminal dots carved on all letters. Use of the classic zeta in line 2.

Three lines of Greek text not centred on stone. Line 2 is shifted significantly to right, in comparison with lines 1 and 3. Guidelines are the top and bottom of each line are still evident, but less pronounced than on
Letters are extremely regular and neat, with letter heights all identical. Letters are thin, tall and evenly spaced. Terminal dots carved on all letters. Use of the classic zeta in line 1.

Four lines of fragmentary Greek text, with missing text on both sides.
Letters are thin and spindly. Letter heights are irregular, as is the spacing between letters. Very flat serifs used on all letters.

1ἔζ(ησεν) ἔτη κγʹ
2ἡμέρας κθʹ
Three lines of Greek text, set within right side of tabula ansata.

All alphas have a broken mid-bar, and the omega in line 1 is tear-drop shaped. Serifs used on most letters. Some irregular spacing between letters, particularly in line 1 between the kappa and omega. Upsilon in line 2 is very long.

1Ἀττικῶν
2Ἀγ̣αθίνου
3χαῖρε

Two columns of Greek funerary texts. Right column intact, but left column is almost completely missing. Perhaps a missing epitaph on the right as well. 4 lines of Greek text in each column, text of both columns is roughly in line. The right column has an unusual stepped indentation of the left margin, with each line starting c.1 character further to the right than the last.
Letters are neat, evenly spaced, but finely incised on stone. Letters bear simple serifs. Epsilons have arrows in place of cross-bar. Short cross-bar of the theta in column 2, line 3.
